Pore/Structural Features.Structure Type: Asymmetric bilayer nanochannels with angstrom-scale cavities, comprising tetrahedral pores (ZIF-8) and triangular, tetrahedral, and octahedral channels (UiO-66-NH2).

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Kinetic sieving; fastest transmembrane conduction due to smallest hydrated diameter and lower hydration energy; cation permselectivity.

Other Information.Test Conditions: Various KCl concentrations (e.g., 0.001-100 mM for I-V, 0.5 M for diffusion, 10 mM for conductance, 50-fold/500-fold salinity gradients)
Other Information.Additional Info: Highest ionic conductance among tested ions. Experiences relatively unimpeded passage compared to larger ions.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Kinetic sieving; transmembrane conduction due to relatively smaller hydrated diameter and lower hydration energy; cation permselectivity.

Other Information.Test Conditions: Various NaCl concentrations (e.g., 0.5 M for diffusion, 5-fold/50-fold/500-fold salinity gradients)
Other Information.Additional Info: Second highest ionic conductance among tested monovalent ions. Experiences relatively unimpeded passage compared to larger ions.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Kinetic sieving; transmembrane conduction requiring dehydration; cation permselectivity.

Other Information.Test Conditions: Various LiCl concentrations (e.g., 0.5 M for diffusion, 500-fold salinity gradient)
Other Information.Additional Info: Experiences higher energy barrier compared to K+/Na+ due to larger hydrated size.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Kinetic sieving; transmembrane conduction requiring significant dehydration; cation permselectivity.

Other Information.Test Conditions: Various CaCl2 concentrations (e.g., 0.5 M for diffusion, 500-fold salinity gradient)
Other Information.Additional Info: Experiences higher energy barrier compared to K+/Na+ due to larger hydrated size. Lower ionic conductance than monovalent ions.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Kinetic sieving; transmembrane conduction requiring significant dehydration; cation permselectivity.

Other Information.Test Conditions: Various MgCl2 concentrations (e.g., 0.5 M for diffusion, 500-fold salinity gradient)
Other Information.Additional Info: Lowest ionic conductance among tested ions due to largest hydrated diameter and highest hydration energy. Experiences highest energy barrier.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Co-ion exclusion; electrostatic repulsion due to negatively charged channels and overlapped electric double layer (EDL).

Other Information.Test Conditions: Various concentrations of KCl, NaCl, LiCl, MgCl2, CaCl2
Other Information.Additional Info: Membrane selectively conducts cations over anions (permselectivity).

Sieving Mechanism: Molecular sieving based on hydrated ionic size exclusion and dehydration-assisted transport, coupled with cation permselectivity facilitated by overlapped electric double layer in asymmetric, negatively charged angstrom-scale nanochannels. Ion transport is influenced by flow direction and hydration energy barriers.

Experimental Validation.Method: I-V curves; Ionic conductance measurements; Diffusion-driven conductivity test; Electrochemical cell osmotic energy conversion; Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations; Zeta potential analysis; FT-IR; XPS; N2 adsorption-desorption; XRD.
Experimental Validation.Performance Metrics: Ionic current rectification (ICR) behavior observed; Ionic conductance order: K+ > Na+ > Li+ > Ca2+ > Mg2+; Maximum osmotic power densities: 0.70 W/m2 (5-fold NaCl), 8.72 W/m2 (50-fold NaCl), 40.01 W/m2 (500-fold NaCl), 66.90 W/m2 (500-fold KCl); Permeability: >665 A/m2 (500-fold salinity gradient); Power density from real sea-river water: 9.20 W/m2; Osmotic energy conversion efficiency: 15.68%; Stable diffusion current for 3600 s with <0.1% change.

Other Information.Additional Info: Bilayer MOF-on-MOF membrane constructed from ZIF-8 deposited on UiO-66-NH2; UiO-66-NH2 layer intercalated with poly(sodium-4-styrenesulfonate) (PSS); ZIF-8 layer grown using polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) as a structure-directing agent; Overall membrane is asymmetric in nanochannel shape, size, and surface charge; Negatively charged channels facilitate cation transport; Bilayer thickness: ~700 nm (UiO-66-NH2(PSS) film: 125 ± 15 nm, ZIF-8(PVP) top layer: 571 ± 18 nm) on a 74.6 μm AAO substrate. Studied for osmotic energy harvesting.
